content:
AUSTRALIA

BHP (BHP AT) - Co. is working on a plan to change the types of coal it produces in NSW to levels preferred by Japanese and Korean customers in response to Chinese import curbs. (AFR)

GBST Holdings (GBT AT) - Bravura Solutions increased its proposal for the Co. to AUD 2.72/Shr from AUD 2.50/Shr. (Newswires)

GPT Group (GPT AT) - Co. sought a trading halt and announced AUD 800mln placement, while it proposed to acquire 25% stake in Darling Park for AUD 531mln. (Newswires)

Link Administration Holdings (LNK AT) - Co. affirms FY19 oper. EBITDA AUD 350mln-360mln. (Newswires)

National Australia Bank (NAB AT) - The search for the bank’s next boss is nearing the finish as the field has been narrowed and candidate assessment almost finalized. (The Australian)

Energy - WTI rose around 4% to above USD 54.00/bbl. (Newswires) - Shell (RDSA LN) us said to be looking at the Australian retail energy sector for acquisition targets. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Daiichi Sankyo (4568 JT) - Co. received approval for VANFLYNTA treatment in Japan. (Newswires)

Japan Display (6740 JT) - Co. reportedly continue talks with TPK Holding (3673 TT) on LCD alliance. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. is proposing creating a new board committee which will include seats for Renault's (RNO FP) Chairman and CEO, while there were separate reports that Nissan and Renault joint operations have discreetly stopped. (Newswires)

Nomura Holdings (8604 JT) - Co. is to conduct a share repurchase of up to JPY 150bln or 8.6% of outstanding shares. (Newswires)

Nomura Research (4307 JT) - Co. is to conduct a buyback valued at JPY 160bln. (Newswires)

Softbank (9984 JT) - Co. will hold its annual general shareholders meeting today. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Corp (8053 JT) - Co. is to sell 49% stake in Sumifru Singapore to TVL. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe will not be holding a one on one meeting with South Korean President Moon at the G20. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hansol Paper (004150 KS) - Co. and Iconex have mutually decided to withdraw from agreement to sell Schades and R+S to Iconex. (Newswires)

Korean Air (003490 KS) - Co. will purchase a total 30 Boeing (BA) 787 planes for USD 9.67bln. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea plans to spend KRW 32tln over the next four years to renovate old public infrastructure and carry out extensive safety inspections. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - Chinese President Xi said China will contribute to negotiation on Korean peninsula. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted that he had a very good telephone conversation with President Xi of China and will be having an extended meeting next week at the G-20, while he also noted that their respective teams will begin talks prior to the meeting. In related news, Chinese state media confirmed that President Xi held a call with US President Trump and that Chinese President Xi has agreed to talk with US President Trump during the G20 Summit, while there were later reports that Chinese President Xi stresses that talks need to be on equal footing to solve China-US trade dispute. Newswires/Twitter/Xinhua)

China Global Times Editor noted in a tweet which was later deleted that the US and Chinese Presidents did agree to meet in which they will discuss fundamental issues in China-US relations, while the editor suggested the phone call brings a slim hope to break the current deadlock between the two countries. (Twitter)

USTR Lighthizer reaffirmed no decision has yet been made on implementing the next round of tariffs on Chinese goods, while he suggested that dialogue has proven to be unsuccessful in achieving trade reform with China and that he is unsure if tariffs alone will stop China cheating but it is the best instrument available. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said US wants to continue China talks to address structural changes and enforcement, while he added that the US position remains that China must make structural changes and USTR Lighthizer will be in touch with Chinese counterparts on trade talks. (Fox News)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam apologised for the divisions caused by the extradition bill and said there is currently no timetable for the bill. Lam also stated that the government will definitely not resume the extradition bill if divisions cannot be resolved and it is unlikely that the bill will be able to make deadline of the end of this legislative term, while she added the extradition bill will expire if it does not reach legislature in current terms. (Newswires)

New Zealand Dairy Price Change -3.8% (Prev. -3.4%) and Whole Milk Powder Price Change -4.3% (Prev. -1.5%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson remained in the lead after the second round of the Conservative leadership vote with 126 votes vs. Jeremy Hunt at 46 votes, Michael Gove at 41 votes, Rory Stewart at 37 votes and Sajid Javid at 33 votes, Dominic Raab was eliminated with 30 votes. (Newswires)

BoE Governor Carney said his comments have no bearing on BoE policy ahead of Thursday's MPC meeting but noted that in exceptional circumstances such as Brexit, the MPC can extend horizon over which it returns to inflation target. (Newswires)

ECB's Draghi said the ECB will use all the flexibility to fulfil the mandate and that the Governing Council will deliberate in the coming weeks how instruments can be adapted corresponding to the severity of the risk to price stability, while he suggested that additional stimulus will be needed if the outlook does not improve. Draghi also stated that APP still has considerable headroom, that the risk outlook remains tilted to the downside and indicators for the coming quarters point to lingering softness. Furthermore, ECB's Draghi said the trigger for action is absence of improvement and that some market-based inflation indicators have lost their information content, while he added that lingering uncertainty is a materialisation of risk. (Newswires)

ECB officials see rate cuts as the primary tool for any new stimulus according to ECB sources, while source reports later noted that ECB policymakers are divided on the next policy step with a rate cut, guidance change and more QE all in play. (Newswires)

  • EU HICP Final (May) Y/Y 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Jun) -21.1 vs. Exp. -5.9 (Prev. -2.1)

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude inventories -0.81mln vs. Exp. -1.1mln (Prev. +4.9mln). (Newswires)

There were initial reports that OPEC and Non-OPEC are discussing on holding ministerial meetings on July 10th-12th as proposed by Iran, although sources later stated that OPEC is to propose holding meeting on July 1st-2nd. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Moscow has agreed to consider an OPEC/OPEC+ meeting on July 12th, while he also commented there is too many uncertainties in the oil market and that it is too early to make a decision on the oil cut deal. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US will maintain the pressure campaign on Iran but also stated that the US has been engaged in many messages with Iran and wants to deter aggression. In related news, US Special Envoy for Iran Hook plans to travel to Paris next week for talks on Iran with British, French and German officials, while there were separate comments from US Air Force General Selva that the US will respond directly to Iran if it engages US forces, and Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Head Salami commented that ballistic missiles are able to hit carriers in the sea with great precision. (Newswires)

 

US

There were initial reports that the White House explored the legality of demoting Fed Chair Powell in February following Trump's comments about firing him. However, US NEC Director Kudlow said the White House is not considering demoting Fed Chair Powell and is not taking any action to change Powell's status, while US President Trump later replied "let's see what he does" when asked whether he wants to demote Fed Chair Powell. (Newswires)

US President Trump criticized ECB's Draghi for announcing more stimulus and suggested it is unfair for US as EUR is weaker. (Twitter)

USTR Lighthizer noted that lawmakers are having constructive dialogue in regards to improving USMCA and hopes to submit a legislation that Congress can approve very soon. (Newswires)

  • US Building Permits Number (May) 1.294M vs. Exp. 1.296M (Prev. 1.29M). (Newswires)
  • US Housing Starts Number (May) 1.269M vs. Exp. 1.239M (Prev. 1.235M, Rev. 1.281M)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks rallied after US President Trump announced a resumption of US/China talks ahead of an “extended meeting” at the G20 Summit (and ECB President Draghi earlier sent European stocks higher on the prospect of further easing). Leading the way was the tech sector, that was also supported by a number of positive stories for its heavy weights. Facebook (FB) moved higher after the co. unveiled further details of its cryptocurrency which is currently enjoying widespread support amongst online vendors. PayPal (PYPL) was under pressure and Western Union (WU) sunk on the prospect of a fresh competitor. Apple (AAPL) opened in the green after reports it would step in to help Japan Display. Amazon (AMZN) moved higher after the co. announced the lease of a further 15 Boeing Freight aircraft, as the e-commerce giant looks to further expand its air network. Boeing (BA) moved higher, after receiving a big order from Korea Air, that ended a slow start for the aircraft maker at the Paris Air Show, and also securing business with Amazon. Tesla (TSLA) jumped higher pre-market on news it would revamp its Asia business, but later fell on the news that legal documents suggested the electric automaker has not met a Model 3 production goal set by Elon Musk. Nvidia (NVDA) moved higher on reports it would team up with Volvo. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) was buoyant after its ULTOMIRIS drug was approved in Japan. Similarly, Merck & Co (MRK) was underpinned by the approval of its Keytruda drug. AT&T (T) opened higher on the news that the telecoms co. had won the bidding for spectrum licenses covering over 98% of the US population. NiSource (NI) opened higher on the news that the utilities co. is mulling the sale of its Columbia Gas of Massachusetts unit for up to USD 2bln, but gave away gains as defensive sectors lagged the broader stock market rally. Dish Network (DISH) moved higher on the news that the co. had launched OnTech Smart Services, a new direct-to-consumer brand that will provide consumers with installation, set-up, and education for smart home devices/entertainment systems. Alibaba (BABA) moved higher on reports the co. is shuffling top executives and business units ahead of its Hong Kong listing. Lennar (LEN) sunk on a downgrade from Raymond James. Allergan (AGN) popped higher on the news that the co. is to announce a split during its Q2 earnings call. Snap (SNAP) jumped higher after receiving its second upgrade of the month. Likewise, Pinterest jumped higher on an upgrade from Wedbush. S&P 500 1% at 2918, NASDAQ-100 1.5% at 7635, Dow Jones 1.4% at 26468.

The curve bull-flattened at settlement, with yields falling across the curve. The complex took influence from the Bund in the European morning after a dovish set of comments from ECB chief Draghi (more stimulus could be on the way unless the data improves), which eventually led to Bund yields hitting fresh record lows, before paring back as risk sentiment improved as Trump signalled progress was being made with China on trade ahead of the G20 meeting. Treasuries, however, remained bid, and 10-year yields fell to a whisker of the psychological 2.00% mark. 3m/10yr inversion deepened by around 6bps on the day, while major curve spreads were narrower by around 1-2bps at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5+ higher at 127-04+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 18th June 2019: US/China talks recommence ahead of G20; Draghi opens door for further ECB stimulus
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump/Xi G20 meeting “extended” confirmed; Draghi paves the way for further ECB stimulus, Trump critical; Saudis to push for tighter compliance; Hong Kong’s Lam puts controversial extradition bill to bed in light of tensions; RBA Minutes hint at looser policy; BoJo tops second conservative leadership vote
  • COMING UP: Japan Exports, Imports, Trade Balance, BoJ’s Kuroda; ECB’s Draghi, Lautenschlager, Coeure; UK CPI; US MBA Mortgage Apps; Canada CPI, BoC Core; FOMC Rate Decision, Fed’s Powell (press conference); New Zealand GDP Production Based

 

* ECB: ECB President Draghi opened the door for further ECB stimulus, saying the central bank will use all flexibility within its mandate to fulfil its policy goals. Draghi specifically said that, in the absence of an improvement in the data, such that the sustained return of inflation to the Bank's aim is threatened, additional stimulus will be required (comments which he later reiterated). Draghi also said that, looking forward, the risk outlook remains tilted to the downside and indicators for the coming quarters point to lingering softness. In the coming weeks, the Governing Council will deliberate how their instruments can be adapted commensurate to the severity of the risk to price stability. He also added that APP still has considerable headroom. A few hours later, ECB sources suggested that ECB officials see rate cuts as the primary tool for any new stimulus. US President Trump criticised ECB President Draghi, saying the announcement of fresh stimulus was “unfair” as it results in a weaker EUR, before later tweeting “Germany's DAX index is up due to ECB's Draghi, (which is) very unfair to the United States!".

* CHINA: Trump announced via Twitter that he had a very good telephone conversation with President Xi of China and will be having an extended meeting next week at the G-20. Moreover, their respective teams will begin talks prior to the meeting. Chinese State Media soon confirmed. Soon after, a provocative tweet from China’s Global Times Editor, which said that “(the trade talks) will discuss fundamental issues in China-US relations. This phone call brings a slim hope to break the current deadlock between the two countries!" was quickly deleted, possibly an indication that Chinese authorities are looking to tone-down hawkish commentary ahead of the G20 meeting. USTR Lighthizer, during a Congressional testimony, reaffirmed that no decision has yet been made on implementing the next round of tariffs on Chinese goods, before also noting that "dialogue is proven to be unsuccessful" in achieving trade reform with China and that he is unsure if tariffs alone will stop China cheating, but it’s the best instrument available.

* US DEFENCE SECRETARY: US President Trump tweeted that acting secretary of defense Patrick Shanahan has decided not to proceed with his confirmation process; Secretary of the Army Mark Esper will be the new acting defense secretary.

* BREXIT: Boris Johnson maintained his lead in the second Conservative Leadership Vote, whilst Dominic Raab was eliminated after securing fewer than 33 votes. The breakdown of the votes were as follows; Boris Johnson 126, Jeremy Hunt 46, Michael Gove 41, Rory Stewart 37, Sajid Javid 33, Dominic Raab 30 (eliminated).

* US HOUSING STARTS: May housing starts came in at 1.269mln, falling by 0.9%, but still above the 1.239mln expected; April was revised higher to 1.281mln. Building permits printed 1.294mln, narrowly missing the expected 1.296mln. Analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics said “the strong-looking starts number is flattered by a big jump in the volatile multi-family component, up 10.9%, while single-family starts fell 6.4% to a three-month low.” However, PM notes how the opposite was true for the permits figures, reversing the April drop in the single-family component. The consultancy goes against the grain and calls on a sustained revival in sales, “If we’re right… new construction will follow.” PM note the multi-family component’s persistent flat trend indicates a flat rate of completions through the fall of 2020 at minimum, “The rental market, therefore, will remain very tight, increasing the upward pressure on rents.”

* FED: Ahead of Wednesday’s Fed meeting, reports emerged that the White House had explored the legality of demoting Fed Chair Powell in February, following Trump's comments about firing him. The news broke just as NEC Director Kudlow was speaking to Fox News, telling the news organisation that the Fed is independent, and has its own timeline for interest rates; Kudlow also said that the White House was not considering demoting Powell, and was not taking any action to change his status.

* PREVIEW: FOMC Rate Decision and Staff Economic Projections (June 2019): The base case is for rates to remain unchanged at 2.25-2.50%; however, messaging is crucial, and there will be focus on the statement and forecasts for any signs the FOMC is mulling lower rates at future meetings; the market is at least expecting the Fed to signal an openness to cut rates should the conditions require. Rate decision and staff economic projections will be published at 1900 BST/1400 EDT on 19th June 2019; post-meeting press conference with Chair Powell to commence at 1930 BST/1430 EDT. To download the report, please click here.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.97 HIGHER AT USD 53.90/BBL; BRENT (Q9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.20 HIGHER AT USD 62.14/BBL: Crude markets took their cues from wider risk sentiment on Tuesday, with a dovish ECB and some China trade resolution hopes seeing risk assets spike higher. Analysts at Citigroup on the driving factors and the WTI/Brent Arb narrowing highlight, “While these are all classified as macro risk-on trade signals, the rally is being led by July WTI, suggesting short covering ahead of Thursday’s contract expiration as the most urgent force behind the move.” The geopolitical tensions are still likely providing support, but WTI is leading, not Brent. As originally proposed by Iran, OPEC+ members are now discussing the July 10th to 12th dates for the anticipated meeting. Pinnacle OPEC member Saudi said it intends to push for tighter compliance to OPEC production curbs. "That will mean producers such as Iraq, Nigeria and other countries that didn’t respect the December agreement will need to abide by the renewed pact,” one Saudi oil adviser said, “The move would reduce crude supplies from these producers by 300,000 to 400,000 barrels a day." However, Russian Energy Minister Novak said there is too many uncertainties in the oil market, and it is too early to decide on the oil cut deal.

* IRAN: Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia and Iran are discussing the joint development of several oilfields at Kaspian Sea, coming after the two countries signed an MOU. In the context of reports that the US was sending additional troops to the Middle East, US General Selva said the US will respond directly to Iran if it engages US forces. US Secretary of State Pompeo later said the US will maintain the pressure campaign on Iran, but does want to deter aggression or war; adding that Washington has been engaged in many messages with Tehran.

* US T-Note futures (M9) settle 5+ higher at 127-04+: The curve bull-flattened at settlement, with yields falling across the curve. The complex took influence from the Bund in the European morning after a dovish set of comments from ECB chief Draghi (more stimulus could be on the way unless the data improves), which eventually led to Bund yields hitting fresh record lows, before paring back as risk sentiment improved as Trump signalled progress was being made with China on trade ahead of the G20 meeting. Treasuries, however, remained bid, and 10-year yields fell to a whisker of the psychological 2.00% mark. 3m/10yr inversion deepened by around 6bps on the day, while major curve spreads were narrower by around 1-2bps at settlement.

* S&P 500 1% at 2918, NASDAQ-100 1.5% at 7635, Dow Jones 1.4% at 26468, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.8%, Consumer Staples -0.6%, Energy 1.4%, Financials 1.3%, Health Care 0.8%, Industrials 1.9%, Information Technology 1.7%, Materials 0.8%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities -0.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Stocks rallied after US President Trump announced a resumption of US/China talks ahead of an “extended meeting” at the G20 Summit (and ECB President Draghi earlier sent European stocks higher on the prospect of further easing). Leading the way was the tech sector, that was also supported by a number of positive stories for its heavy weights. Facebook (FB) moved higher after the co. unveiled further details of its cryptocurrency which is currently enjoying widespread support amongst online vendors. PayPal (PYPL) was under pressure and Western Union (WU) sunk on the prospect of a fresh competitor. Apple (AAPL) opened in the green after reports it would step in to help Japan Display. Amazon (AMZN) moved higher after the co. announced the lease of a further 15 Boeing Freight aircraft, as the e-commerce giant looks to further expand its air network. Boeing (BA) moved higher, after receiving a big order from Korea Air, that ended a slow start for the aircraft maker at the Paris Air Show, and also securing business with Amazon. Tesla (TSLA) jumped higher pre-market on news it would revamp its Asia business, but later fell on the news that legal documents suggested the electric automaker has not met a Model 3 production goal set by Elon Musk. Nvidia (NVDA) moved higher on reports it would team up with Volvo. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) was buoyant after its ULTOMIRIS drug was approved in Japan. Similarly, Merck & Co (MRK) was underpinned by the approval of its Keytruda drug. AT&T (T) opened higher on the news that the telecoms co. had won the bidding for spectrum licenses covering over 98% of the US population. NiSource (NI) opened higher on the news that the utilities co. is mulling the sale of its Columbia Gas of Massachusetts unit for up to USD 2bln, but gave away gains as defensive sectors lagged the broader stock market rally. Dish Network (DISH) moved higher on the news that the co. had launched OnTech Smart Services, a new direct-to-consumer brand that will provide consumers with installation, set-up, and education for smart home devices/entertainment systems. Alibaba (BABA) moved higher on reports the co. is shuffling top executives and business units ahead of its Hong Kong listing. Lennar (LEN) sunk on a downgrade from Raymond James. Allergan (AGN) popped higher on the news that the co. is to announce a split during its Q2 earnings call. Snap (SNAP) jumped higher after receiving its second upgrade of the month. Likewise, Pinterest jumped higher on an upgrade from Wedbush.

* FX WRAP: EUR was sent reeling after ECB President Draghi opened the door for further monetary stimulus, EURUSD falling back below the 1.1200 handle. Naturally, USD saw strength, with DXY moving above resistance at 97.60. The buck also saw some upside against JPY after Trump announced the resumption of China trade talks after his call with President Xi, albeit USDJPY remains well with its June 107.80-108.80 range. The announcement saw CNY spike higher, USDCNY pressing back towards 6.9000. The China exposed antipodeans also rose; AUDUSD breaking back above 0.6850. Meanwhile, CAD was also a beneficiary, moving higher as risk appetite returned to the market and the crude complex rallied. GBP moved sideways, ahead of tonight’s televised Conservative leadership debate and Thursday BoE MPC meeting. The strong rebound in risk appetite and subsequent gain in crude prices saw NOK move higher against EUR, in contrast to SEK, which failed to sustain gains irrespective of independent Euro weakness and some upbeat Swedish impulses via the SNDO and Riksbank business survey. EMFX rallied almost across the board, first on dovish Draghi, second on the news of a restart in US/China trade talks.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: ECB and US Presidents in the spotlight ahead of the Fed
content:
USD

The Dollar is mixed vs major counterparts, but down against most EM currencies amidst a broader upturn in risk sentiment following dovish comments from ECB President Draghi and tweets from US President Trump. To recap, the former sounded much less confident about the Eurozone inflation outlook and downside risks to price stability at Sintra, and said that if absent of any improvement in the next few weeks then additional stimulus will be necessary, while sources subsequently suggested that the primary tool in this event would be a rate cut. Meanwhile, after criticising Draghi for effectively talking the Euro down, the latter announced that he and his Chinese peer Xi talked on the phone and agreed to hold extended meetings at the upcoming G20, with trade talks to resume ahead of the Summit in Japan. The DXY has rebounded firmly from sub-97.400 lows to 97.770 and just shy of June highs at 97.802 as attention turns to the FOMC and culmination of the 2-day meeting to see if a July rate cut is flagged, as widely expected, or if the Fed disappoints with a more incremental shift in language towards easing at some stage – see our headline feed or research suite for a more detailed preview of the June policy gathering.

EUR

As noted above, the single currency was hit hard by Draghi’s forthright remarks and Eur/Usd is hovering a few ticks above 1.1180 compared to 1.1240 or so at one stage, while Eur/GBP has retreated some 50 pips from top to bottom (0.8974-22) even though the Pound remains shaky ahead of the 2nd Tory leadership vote and results due around 18.00BST. Indeed, Cable is veering towards the base of a 1.2507-44 range and also awaiting the BBC debate that favourite Boris Johnson is scheduled to take part in.

NZD/AUD/CAD

All beneficiaries of the aforementioned constructive US-China trade news (which Beijing essentially confirmed) and resultant rebound in risk appetite, as Nzd/Usd extended above 0.6500 and largely ignored hefty declined in GDT prices ahead of NZ Q1 current account data later. Similarly, Aud/Usd pared a chunk of its overnight losses prompted by RBA minutes underscoring market expectations for further reductions in the OCR to trade back up near 0.6875 vs circa 0.6830 at one stage. The Loonie overcame another Chinese import ban and much worse than forecast Canadian manufacturing sales with the aid of the overall improvement in sentiment, but also some momentum surrounding USMCA. Usd/Cad back down around 1.3400 within 1.3385-3432 parameters.

CHF/JPY 

The Franc slipped a bit further below parity vs the Buck and pared some gains against the Euro as the mood improved and initial post-Draghi positioning waned, while the Yen slumped on a sharp unwind of safe-haven flows/hedging to trade down at 108.67 from 108.07 at best.

NOK/ZAR

The more upbeat mood has bolstered the Norwegian Krona alongside a strong rebound in oil prices pre-API, with the Eur/Nok down through 9.7750 in contrast to Eur/SEK that failed to sustain gains irrespective of independent Euro weakness and some upbeat Swedish impulses via the SNDO and Riksbank business survey. The cross is hovering around 10.6500 vs 10.6147 at the low and a peak around 10.6600. Conversely, the Rand benefited from the risk-on tone and SA headlines that President Ramaphosa will pump more aid into Eskom to help it recover and stabilise. Usd/Zar now closer to 14.5000 than 14.8240 at the session pinnacle.

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is reportedly willing to help Japan Display (6740 JT) amid sluggish iPhone sales, according to sources cited by WSJ.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence), Airbus (AIR FP, EADSY) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) - Korean Air has ordered 20 Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft and agreed to lease another 10. The deal includes a commitment to purchase a further 10 new 787-10s and 10 additional 787-9 airplanes, valuing the total agreement at USD 6.3bln (at current prices). The order hands Boeing a much-needed boost following a slow start to the Paris Airshow, in which Airbus logged 123 orders on the first day to Boeing’s nil. Elsewhere, Air Lease (AL) placed an additional order with for five Boeing 787-9 Dreamliners, whilst Amazon (AMZN) leased 15 737-800 jets.
  • JP Morgan Chase (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is reportedly working on a digital banking project in London, newswires reported citing sources. Sources say the bank is “busy hiring high level developers with full-stack and cloud-based dev skills for the new project, along with other personnel."
  • Merck & Co (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that the FDA has approved its KEYTRUDA cancer therapy drug. Elsewhere, Merck & Co and AstraZeneca (AZN LN, AZN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that the European Commission has approved their LYNPARZA drug, which treats ovarian, fallopian tube or primary peritoneal cancer.
  • Microsoft (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) has resumed sales of its Huawei laptops as it looks to get sell down its existing inventory. The co. added that it believes it can continued to provide updates to people who have already own Huawei devices.
  • United Technologies’ (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) Collins Aerospace has secured over USD 1.5bln in agreements covering its Power & Controls and Aerostructures business units.
  • Verizon (VZ) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) - US Senator Rubio has filed legislation aiming to block Huawei from seeking damages in US patent courts. This follows the Chinese tech co. making demands that Verizon pay USD 1bln for patented technology.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) and Sanofi (SAN FP) announced a joint venture which aims to use emerging data technologies to change how medicines and health services are delivered.
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) announced on Tuesday that it would lease 15 Boeing 737-800 cargo, through a partnership with General Electric's (GE) GE Capital Aviation Services. The 15 aircraft will be in addition to the five Boeing 737-800s already leased from GECAS, announced earlier this year as the e-commerce giant looks to further expands its air network.
  • Cognizant (CTSH) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) announced that it has agreed to buy Zenith Technologies, a private life sciences technology company based in Cork, Ireland.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has unveiled plans to launch its cryptocurrency, called Libra, marking the social media co.’s latest effort to expand beyond social networking and move into online financial services.
  • Nvidia (NVDA) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) and Volvo (VOLVF) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) have partnered to jointly develop a decision-making system for autonomous vehicles and machines.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is to reportedly to re-vamp its Asia business as the electric automaker shifts its focus to China.

S&P 500

  • Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced that Japan's MHLW has approved its ULTOMIRIS drug, a treatment for adult patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. The approval is based on results from two Phase 3 studies which demonstrated solid results.
  • AT&T (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) has won the bidding for spectrum licenses covering over 98% of the US population, following the close of FCC Auction 102. Elsewhere, the telecoms co.’s WarnerMedia unit is reportedly nearing a deal with Star Wars: The Force Awakens director JJ Abrams, reported the NYT. 
  • CBS Corp (CBS, CBSA) (Communication Services/Broadcasting), The E.W. Scripps Company (SSP) (Communication Services/Broadcasting), Fox (FOXA) (Communication Services/Broadcasting), TEGNA Inc. (TGNA) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) – The DoJ has reached settlements with CBS Corp, Cox Enterprises, The E.W. Scripps Company, Fox Corporation, and TEGNA Inc. to resolve an ongoing investigation into exchanges of competitively sensitive information within the broadcast television industry.
  • Dish Network (DISH) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) has launched OnTech Smart Services, a new direct-to-consumer brand that will provide consumers with installation, set-up, and education for smart home devices/entertainment systems.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) Aviation GE booked over USD 24bln in new orders for engines and services on the first day of the Paris Air Show. This included the largest engine order of all time, in which Indigo Airlines placed a USD 20bln order for GE Aviation’s CFM International LEAP-1A engines.
  • Kellogg Co. (K) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) has announced a reorganization plan, which will primarily impact operations in North America, in anticipation of pending divestiture of businesses to Ferrero International SA, with the project expected to be completed by the end of 2019.
  • NiSource Inc (NI) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) is reportedly mulling the sale of its Columbia Gas of Massachusetts unit. Reportedly the division could fetch USD 2bln, but is facing in excess of USD 1bln in disaster claims after last years deadly pipeline explosion.
  • Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) and Northrop Grumman (NOC) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) are teaming up to integrate Northrop Grumman's scramjet combustors into Raytheon's hypersonic weapons. Elsewhere, Raytheon are teaming up with Black Sage to provide drone detection and mitigation systems.

OTHER

  • Caesers Entertainment (CZR) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) activist shareholder Carl Icahn thinks the casino co. is demanding too much in its buyout talks with Eldorado Resorts (ERI), reported the NYT.
  • Spirit AeroSystems (SPR) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) announced its role in Airbus’ (AIR FP, EADSY) Wing of Tomorrow program, to which it will contribute the development of solutions essential for the fabrication and assembly of leading edges, wing boxes and lower wing covers.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • ECB President Draghi said additional stimulus will be required if inflation aim is threatened, APP still has considerable headroom
  • Stocks surge as Draghi strikes a dovish tone, albeit Financials underperform amid the prolongation of negative rates
  • EUR slumped to the bottom of the G10 pile amid dovish Draghi comments, DXY is firmer above 97.50
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Building Permits, Housing Starts, APIs, Tory Leadership Vote, ECB’s Draghi, BoE’s Carney

18th June 2019

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets mostly saw cautious gains ahead of this week’s key risk events and following the marginal gains in the US where trade was otherwise uneventful aside from the strength in tech and telecoms. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were mixed with Australia led higher by tech and commodity related sectors, in which government plans to introduce a AUD 158bln income tax cut package, as well as anticipation for further RBA policy easing, added to the optimism. Tokyo sentiment was hampered by a firmer currency. Hang Seng (+1.0%) outperformed as business returned to normal following the recent protests and the Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) was indecisive despite continued PBoC liquidity efforts, as trade uncertainty lingered after economic regulators refused to rule out using rare earths in the trade dispute and the Global Times Editor suggested the potential for a protracted trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially traded steady amid the indecisiveness in the region but were later supported as sentiment in Japan further deteriorated and after the 5yr auction results showed a decline in yields and higher accepted prices from the prior month.

PBoC injected CNY 90bln via 14-day reverse repo for a daily net injection of CNY 80bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8942 (Prev. 6.8940)

Chinese House Prices (May) Y/Y 10.7% (Prev. 10.7%). (Newswires)

China April UST holdings at USD 1.113trln (prev. USD 1.121trln in March); 2yr low. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Leader Lam says the government will definitely not resume the extradition bill if divisions cannot be resolved. (Newswires)

 

RBA minutes from the June 4th meeting stated the board agreed more likely than not that further policy easing would be appropriate, and the labour market would be particularly important on deciding further easing. The board also judged that the rate cut would help reduce spare capacity in the labour market, while it noted that factors limiting inflation and wage growth are likely to remain for some time. (Newswires)

 

ECB

ECB's Draghi said the ECB will use all the flexibility within our mandate to fulfill their mandate, and added that in the absence of improvement, such that the sustained return of inflation to the Bank's aim is threatened, additional stimulus will be required, APP still has considerable headroom. Draghi also noted that in the coming weeks, the Governing Council will deliberate how their instruments can be adapted commensurate to the severity of the risk to price stability and looking forward, the risk outlook remains tilted to the downside, and indicators for the coming quarters point to lingering softness. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond is said to be prepared to resign over PM May's legacy spending plans, although this was dismissed by Treasury sources. (Daily Mail/ITV)

Boris Johnson allies reportedly plan to rig the leadership contest by ‘lending’ votes to Jeremy Hunt so that he faces off against Hunt, who is seen to be struggling, and avoid Michael Gove. (The Sun)

Italian Economy Minister Tria expects Italy's budget deficit in 2019 to be between 2.1-2.2%, will try reach an agreement with the European Commission, confident that a positive outcome can be reached. (Newswires)

EU HICP Final YY (May) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires) German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Jun) -21.1 vs. Exp. -5.9 (Prev. -2.1)

 

 

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +1.2%] as the region was bolstered by a dovish Draghi. The DAX (+1.2%) is now back above the 12k level after having visited a pre-Draghi low of 11,986, albeit gains are somewhat limited by a subdued IT sector, meanwhile, the FTSE 100 lags as the index fails to benefit from Draghi’s speech. In terms of sectors, financial names underperform amid the prolongation of negative rates. Defensive sectors are outperforming with healthcare and utilities the standout outperformers.  Movers to the downside today include chipmakers following a profit warning from Siltronic (-13.0%) , citing US-China trade issues. The downbeat market outlook spilled onto STMicroelectronics (-2.0%), ASML (-1.2%) and Infineon (-5.7%), albeit the latter is more influenced by the launch of a capital increase to fund the Cypress Semiconductor acquisition. Finally, Lufthansa shares rest near the foot of the Stoxx 600 following three separate broker downgrades.

 

FX

EUR/AUD/NZD - The single currency has slumped to the bottom of the G10 pile and even below the Aussie that was hit overnight by RBA minutes flagging further easing on the basis that benign inflation and wage trends are likely to persist for even longer. In similar vein, ECB President Draghi used the stage at Sintra to deliver a much more dovish/downbeat assessment of price developments and all but signalled another tweak to official guidance at the next policy meeting, if not further stimulus. In short, he acknowledged the recent pronounced drop in inflation expectations and said the GC will look at measures to counter the severity of risks to price severity in coming weeks, and if the situation fails to improve more stimulus will be needed. Eur/Usd has reversed from circa 1.1240 to just over 1.1180 and through 2.1 bn option expiries between 1.1195-1.1205 that may yet influence direction into the NY cut, while Eur/Gbp has pulled back sharply from around 0.8975 to 0.8925. Back down under, Aud/Usd is hovering off 0.6832 lows and Aud/Nzd has reversed towards 1.0500 as the Kiwi keeps tabs on the 0.6500 handle vs its US counterpart ahead of the latest GDT auction and NZ Q1 current account data.

CAD/CHF/GBP - All weaker vs the Greenback and partly in sympathy with the Euro and Aussie, but the Loonie also had more negative Chinese-Canadian headlines to digest as Beijing suspended pork imports pending closer inspection of the product. Meanwhile, the Franc slipped through parity, but strengthened in Eur/Chf cross terms to 1.1175 at one stage and will do doubt arouse SNB attention given that the ECB seems to be on the brink of easing further (-10 bp now priced in for December). Elsewhere, Cable is now eyeing 1.2500 and very early January lows after breaching key support at 1.2560, with the next leg of the Tory leadership race looming before UK CPI, retail sales and the BoE unfolds tomorrow and Thursday.

JPY/NOK/SEK - The major outperformers, as the Yen regains a safe-haven bid to retest support ahead of 108.00, while the Scandi Crowns benefit from single currency weakness and ECB-Norges Bank/Riksbank policy divergence given a widely expected hike from the former on Thursday. Moreover, the Sek derived some traction from a cautiously upbeat Riksbank business survey and significantly improved 2019 budget surplus forecasts from the SNDO. Eur/Nok around 9.7780 vs 9.8170 at one stage and Eur/Sek holding within a 10.6484-6147 range.

EM - Although the Buck has rebounded firmly, if not quite uniformly as noted above (back over 97.500), the Lira has maintained recovery momentum with the aid of some rare constructive comments on the US-Turkey front and reports that talks about the S-400 deal will be held at NATO next week. Usd/Try trading near the base of a 5.8225-8777 band.

 

FIXED INCOME

Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have all rallied further to post fresh intraday peaks, at 172.52, 130.75 and 127-22+ respectively, with the former gleaning extra traction after breaching another chart resistance level at 172.42 along the way and also taking on board a rather worrying ZEW survey. Meanwhile, UK bonds have acknowledged a solid 10 year DMO sale and USTs are seeing more bull-flattening ahead of US housing data and FOMC day 1. Note, the corresponding cash yields are also crossing or approaching key lines, as Bunds edge below -30 bp, Gilts eye 80 bp and the 10 year Treasury inches towards 2%.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are lower on the day with the former just above the USD 51.50/bbl level whilst the latter hovers around the USD 60.50/bbl mark. News-flow for the complex was largely surrounding OPEC this morning, with WSJ noting that Saudi intends to push for tighter compliance to OPEC production curbs. Sources also stated that the renewed pact would see the under-complying countries reducing crude supply by 300-400k BPD. In terms of a date, IFX reported that Moscow has reportedly agreed to consider an OPEC+ meeting on July 12th, postponed from the scheduled June 25/26. Looking ahead, traders will be keeping an eye on tonight API inventory release with the street looking for a draw of around 1.75mln barrels. Elsewhere, gold is hovering near intraday highs amid a bout of demand for the safe haven asset. Meanwhile, copper prices are supported despite the underlying risk off tone in the market as Glencore has shut down its Mufulira copper smelter at its Mopani copper mine in Zambia whilst Chile's Codelco said the Chuquicamata copper mine maintained output capacity at 50% due to the 4th full day of a union strike.

Chile's Codelco said the Chuquicamata copper mine maintained output capacity at 50% due to the 4th full day of a union strike. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US is preparing to send additional troops to the Middle East due to Iran threat according to officials. In related news, there were comments from Iran's ambassador to the UK who suggested Iran is unfortunately heading towards a confrontation. (Newswires)

US Acting Defence Secretary Shanahan and Turkish Defence Minister are to meet next week to discuss the S-400 issue at the NATO Ministerial next week

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +1.0%] as the region was bolstered by a dovish Draghi. The DAX (+0.8%) is now back above the 12k level after having visited a pre-Draghi low of 11,986, albeit gains are somewhat limited by a subdued IT sector, meanwhile, the FTSE 100 lags as the index fails to benefit from Draghi’s speech. In terms of sectors, financial names underperform amid the prolongation of negative rates. Defensive sectors are outperforming with healthcare and utilities the standout outperformers.  Movers to the downside today include chipmakers following a profit warning from Siltronic (-13.8%) , citing US-China trade issues. The downbeat market outlook spilled onto STMicroelectronics (-2.3%), ASM (-1.0%) and Infineon (-5.0%), albeit the latter is more influenced by the launch of a capital increase to fund the Cypress Semiconductor acquisition. Finally, Lufthansa shares rest near the foot of the Stoxx 600 following three separate broker downgrades.

EUR/AUD/NZD - The single currency has slumped to the bottom of the G10 pile and even below the Aussie that was hit overnight by RBA minutes flagging further easing on the basis that benign inflation and wage trends are likely to persist for even longer. In short, he acknowledged the recent pronounced drop in inflation expectations and said the GC will look at measures to counter the severity of risks to price severity in coming weeks, and if the situation fails to improve more stimulus will be needed. subject: Dovish Draghi boosts bonds and blasts Euro
content: Bunds and Eurozone debt peers have sharply extended gains on the ECB President’s Sintra revelations that are decidedly more dovish than his most recent post-policy meeting rhetoric and assessment of inflation and growth developments. Bunds just topped out at 172.40 (+84 ticks) and BTPs hit 133.55 (+140 ticks) as Italian Economy Minister Tria repeats hopes that EDP can be avoided, while even Gilts and US Treasuries have benefited to the tune of 45 ticks at 130.63 and 8 ticks at 127-185. However, the Euro has erased and reversed gains to a low of circa 1.1188 vs the Dollar from just over 1.1240 at one stage and is now testing the base of hefty option expiries either side of 1.1200.

ECB's Draghi says the ECB will use all the flexibility within our mandate to fulfill their mandate
content:
• In the coming weeks, the Governing Council will deliberate how their instruments can be adapted commensurate to the severity of the risk to price stability
  • In the absence of improvement, such that the sustained return of inflation to the Bank's aim is threatened, additional stimulus will be required
  • Looking forward, the risk outlook remains tilted to the downside, and indicators for the coming quarters point to lingering softness
  • APP still has considerable headroom
reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction to the dovishly perceived comments from Draghi, EUR/USD fell 37 pips from 1.1236 to 1.1199, Sep'19 Bunds rose 37 ticks from 171.70 to break a contract high and reach 172.07, Dax'19 future saw less of a sustained move, rising 13 points from 12,002 to 12,015
analysis_details: • Note, the next meeting will take place on July 25th

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures conform to positive leads
content: Only a faint lag and fade off early Liffe highs for the 10 year UK benchmark ahead of the new 2020 DMO launch that may yet warrant a bit more in the way of concession, while the STIR strip is cautiously firmer and also seemingly unperturbed by expectations that the BoE may counter the broad global trend and turn more hawkish on Thursday. Looking at price action so far in more detail, Gilts are holding between 130.34-22 vs yesterday’s 130.17 settlement and 3 month contracts are flat to 1 tick ahead vs +1.5 ticks at best. Note, Governor Carney is appearing on a panel at the ECB’s Sintra conference this afternoon, but unlikely to touch upon policy so close to the aforementioned MPC meeting.

Riksbank Business Survey:  Economic activity is still good according to major Swedish companies, but, as earlier, they expect a weakening in the period ahead
content:
• Companies in the manufacturing sector in general perceive the current economic situation as good. However, export companies see increased risks for economic activity in the world as a consequence of the ongoing trade conflicts
  • While unease has increased in the manufacturing sector, the situation is more stable in the trade and construction sectors
  • The relatively weak krona is generally increasing export companies’ profits, but several companies repeatedly state that, above all, they want a stable and predictable currency, as this facilitates their long-term planning

subject: Bunds: attempting to overcome resistance ahead of 172.00 again
content: The core Eurozone bond looks braced for another assault on the contract high and just touched interim chart resistance around 171.75 after opening at 171.54 and slipping to an early Eurex low of 171.51 vs Monday’s 171.56 close. Dovish global Central Bank vibes have been stoked by the latest RBA minutes flagging further easing, while global trade and geopolitical impulses continue to underpin safe-haven debt and similar assets like Gold, the Yen and Swiss Franc. Ahead, final Eurozone inflation data and April’s trade balance are unlikely to impact, but the June ZEW survey could be market-moving given it’s more timely nature and as a potential proxy for preliminary PMIs on Friday. Note also, several ECB speakers are scheduled to speak at Sintra and will be monitored for any sign of a change in policy leaning given the ongoing decline in 5 year/5 year break-evens, and oil prices.

Asian equity markets mostly saw cautious gains ahead of this week’s key risk events and following the marginal performance in US where trade was otherwise uneventful aside from the strength in tech and telecoms. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were mixed with Australia led higher by tech and commodity related sectors, in which government plans to introduce a AUD 158bln income tax cut package, as well as anticipation for further RBA policy easing, added to the optimism. Meanwhile, Tokyo sentiment was hampered by a firmer currency and with Tokai Carbon dragged on M&A activity in which it will acquire Germany’s COBEX in a deal valued at JPY 100bln. (+0.1%) was indecisive despite continued PBoC liquidity efforts, as trade uncertainty lingered after economic regulators refused to rule out using rare earths in the trade dispute and the Global Times Editor suggested the potential for a protracted trade war.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets mostly saw cautious gains ahead of this week’s key risk events and following the marginal gains in the US
  • Boris Johnson allies reportedly plan to rig the leadership contest by ‘lending’ votes to Jeremy Hunt
  • DXY continued on from the prior day’s swings and slipped back below 97.50 amid tentativeness heading into the key central bank meetings
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German ZEW, EZ CPI, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, APIs, Tory Leadership Vote, ECB’s Draghi, de Guindos, Lane, BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets mostly saw cautious gains ahead of this week’s key risk events and following the marginal gains in the US where trade was otherwise uneventful aside from the strength in tech and telecoms. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were mixed with Australia led higher by tech and commodity related sectors, in which government plans to introduce a AUD 158bln income tax cut package, as well as anticipation for further RBA policy easing, added to the optimism. Tokyo sentiment was hampered by a firmer currency. Hang Seng (+0.8%) outperformed as business returned to normal following the recent protests and the Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) was indecisive despite continued PBoC liquidity efforts, as trade uncertainty lingered after economic regulators refused to rule out using rare earths in the trade dispute and the Global Times Editor suggested the potential for a protracted trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially traded steady amid the indecisiveness in the region but were later supported as sentiment in Japan further deteriorated and after the 5yr auction results showed a decline in yields and higher accepted prices from the prior month.

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond is said to be prepared to resign over PM May's legacy spending plans. (Daily Mail/ITV)

Boris Johnson allies reportedly plan to rig the leadership contest by ‘lending’ votes to Jeremy Hunt so that he faces off against Hunt, who is seen to be struggling, and avoid Michael Gove. (The Sun)

Up to a third of PM May's top team could be replaced by a new group of up and coming politicians being lined up to sit in a Boris Johnson Cabinet, according to reports. (Telegraph)

The sticking point in Italy's budget fight with the EU is regarding 2020 as the Treasury sees 2020 deficit at around 1.8% of GDP and ruling parties want it higher. (Newswires)

Italian League lawmaker Centemero said there are banks in Southern Italy that could default and that the parliamentary committee is set to approve tax measures to ease mergers for the banks. (Newswires)

FX

DXY continued on from the prior day’s swings and slipped back below 97.50 amid tentativeness heading into the key central bank meetings and as its major counterparts traded mixed with EUR/USD firmer after having broken above its 20- and 50- DMAs. GBP/USD printed fresh 6-month lows after reports that UK Chancellor Hammond was said to be prepared to resign over PM May's legacy spending plans and there were also reports Boris Johnson allies plan to rig the leadership contest by lending votes to Jeremy Hunt in an effort to avoid a run-off against Michael Gove. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were subdued as a lack of risk appetite in Japan spurred flows into the safe haven JPY and with the downside also triggered by declines in antipodean-related crosses after the RBA Minutes stated the board agreed more likely than not further policy easing would be appropriate and that factors limiting inflation, as well as wage growth are likely to remain for some time.

 

RBA minutes from the June 4th meeting stated the board agreed more likely than not that further policy easing would be appropriate, and the labour market would be particularly important on deciding further easing. The board also judged that the rate cut would help reduce spare capacity in the labour market, while it noted that factors limiting inflation and wage growth are likely to remain for some time. (Newswires)

 

Australian House Price Index (Q1) Q/Q -3.0% vs. Exp. -2.5% (Prev. -2.4%). (Newswires) Australian House Price Index (Q1) Y/Y -7.4% vs. Exp. -6.9% (Prev. -5.1%)

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were uneventful as price action reflected the sideways trade seen across most asset classes with WTI crude futures little changed below the USD 52.00/bbl level after geopolitical tensions failed to lift prices and as the expiration of July WTI options contributed towards the prior day’s mundane tone. Elsewhere, gold was equally unexciting with focus fully centred on the upcoming FOMC although minimal upside was seen in the precious metal due to a slightly softer USD, while copper also flatlined as it held on to Monday’s gains amid an ongoing strike which reduced output to 50% at Codelco’s Chuquicamata copper mine which is the largest open pit copper mine in the world.

Oil production at Libya's Gialo oilfield (130k BPD) is expected to be halted for ten days due to pipeline maintenance, according to NOC. (Newswires)

Chile's Codelco said the Chuquicamata copper mine maintained output capacity at 50% due to the 4th full day of a union strike. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US is preparing to send additional troops to the Middle East due to Iran threat according to officials. In related news, there were comments from Iran's ambassador to the UK who suggested Iran is unfortunately heading towards a confrontation. (Newswires)

North Korea may have produced around 12 more nuclear weapons over the past year, according to reports citing speculation by a Swedish think tank. (Chosun/Twitter)

US

Monday’s uneventful session was evident in the Tplex too, which saw US 10 years move sideways. Early on USTs moved in sympathy with the Bund, which saw fresh record low yields, before catching some mild bidding on the back of the disappointing US NY Fed manufacturing data. At settlement yields were mainly unchanged aside from the front-end, where the 2-year yield rose by c. 1.5bps, which saw the 2s/10s flatten by c. 2bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 1 tick higher at 126-31.

content:

ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are mixed with Australia led higher by tech and commodity related sectors and with government plans to introduce a AUD 158bln income tax cut package as well as anticipation of further RBA policy easing adding to the optimism. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) outperforms as business returns to normal following the recent protests and the Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) is indecisive despite continued PBoC liquidity efforts, as trade uncertainty lingers after economic regulators refused to rule out using rare earths in the trade dispute and with the Global Times Editor suggesting the potential for a protracted trade war.

In FX markets, the DXY continued on from the prior day’s swings to slip back below the 97.50 level amid tentativeness heading into the key central bank meetings and as its major counterparts trade mixed with EUR/USD firmer after having broken above its 20- and 50-DMAs, while Morgan Stanley recently recommended long EUR/USD as its trade of the week. Conversely, GBP/USD printed fresh 6-month lows after reports that UK Chancellor Hammond is said to be prepared to resign over PM May's legacy spending plans and there were also reports Boris Johnson allies plan to rig the leadership contest by lending votes to Jeremy Hunt in an effort to avoid a run-off against Michael Gove. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are subdued as a lack of risk appetite in Japan spurs flows into the safe haven JPY and with the downside also triggered by declines in antipodean-related crosses after the RBA Minutes stated the board agreed more likely than not further policy easing would be appropriate and factors limiting inflation as well as wage growth are likely to remain for some time.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are steady despite the cautiousness in the region with participants sidelined ahead of a 5yr auction later.

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the June 4th meeting where the central bank cut rates by 25bps to a fresh record low of 1.25% as expected, due at 0230BST/2030CDT/0930HKT
content:
At the meeting, the RBA cut the Cash Rate Target to 1.25% which was unanimously expected as ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had priced in a 100% probability for rates to be cut. The RBA stated that it took the decision to lower rates to support employment growth and provide greater confidence inflation will be consistent with medium-term targets.

The RBA noted the main domestic uncertainty continues to be household consumption but added that some pick-up in growth in household income is expected and should support consumption growth. In terms of forecasts, its central scenario is for economy to grow 2.75% this year and next, while underlying inflation is seen at 1.75% this year and 2.00% next year.

The initial reaction in AUD/USD to the rate announcement was to the upside despite the RBA cutting rates for the 1st time in nearly 3 years, as the market was heavily one-sided going into the decision and as the statement didn’t provide anything that suggested urgency by the central bank to cut again as soon as August which many forecasters anticipate. However, RBA Governor Lowe commented a few hours after the rate decision in which he stated it is not unreasonable to expect a lower cash rate from here and that the economic forecast has assumed rates at 1% by year-end.
